bcipy.kernels.absolute module#

class bcipy.kernels.absolute.AbsoluteKernel(graph, inA, outA)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Calculate the element-wise absolute value of Tensor elements

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • Input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

classmethod add_absolute_node(graph, inA, outA)[source]#

Factory method to create an absolute value kernel and add it to a graph as a generic node object.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • Input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel function with the input trial data

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data

initialize()[source]#

Initialize the kernel if there is an internal state to initialize, including downstream initialization data

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#

Calculate the absolute value of the input data, and assign it to the output data

verify()[source]#

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized

bcipy.kernels.cdf module#

Created on Wed Mar 11 10:38:01 2020

@author: ivanovn

class bcipy.kernels.cdf.CDFKernel(graph, inA, outA, dist, df, loc, scale)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Calculates the CDF for a distribution given a RV as input. Currently supports normal and chi2 distributions

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor object

  • First input trial data

outATensor object

  • Output trial data

diststr, {‘norm’, ‘chi2’}

  • Distribution type

dfshape_like

  • The shape parameter(s) for the distribution. See scipy.stats.chi2 docstring for more detailed information

locarray_like, default = 0

  • Location Parameter

scalearray_like, default = 1

  • Scale Parameter

classmethod add_cdf_node(graph, inA, outA, dist='norm', df=None, loc=0, scale=1)[source]#

Factory method to create a CDF node

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel and calculate the CDF

initialization_execution()[source]#
initialize()[source]#

No internal state to setup

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#
verify()[source]#

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized and typed

bcipy.kernels.classifier_ module#

class bcipy.kernels.classifier_.ClassifierKernel(graph, inA, classifier, outA, initialization_data, labels)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Classify data using BCIP Classifier Object

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor object (n_channels, n_samples)

  • Input trial data

classifierClassifier object

  • BCIP Classifier object to be used for classification

outAScalar object

  • Output trial data

initialization_dataTensor object, (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples)

  • Initialization data to train the classifier

labelsTensor object, (n_trials, )

  • Labels corresponding to initialization data class labels

  • (n_trials, 2) for class separated data where column 1 is the trial label and column 2 is the start index

classmethod add_classifier_node(graph, inA, classifier, outA, initialization_data, labels)[source]#

Factory method to create a classifier kernel and add it to a graph as a generic node object

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor object (n_channels, n_samples)

  • Input trial data

classifierClassifier object

  • BCIP Classifier object to be used for classification

outAScalar object

  • Output trial data

initialization_dataTensor object, (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples)

  • Initialization data to train the classifier

labelsTensor object, (n_trials, )

  • Labels corresponding to initialization data class labels

  • (n_trials, 2) for class separated data where column 1 is the trial label and column 2 is the start index

execute()[source]#

Execute single trial classification

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data. Called if downstream nodes are missing training data

initialize()[source]#

Generic initialization abstract method to be defined by individual kernels.

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#

Process data according to outlined kernel function

train_classifier()[source]#
verify()[source]#

similar verification process to individual classifier kernels

bcipy.kernels.concatenation module#

Created on Tue Dec 10 10:52:43 2019

concate.py - Defines a concatenation kernel that concatenates multiple tensors into a single tensor

@author: ivanovn

class bcipy.kernels.concatenation.ConcatenationKernel(graph, outA, inA, inB, axis)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Kernel to concatenate multiple tensors into a single tensor

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • First input trial data

inBTensor or Scalar object

  • Second input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

axisint or tuple of ints, default = 0

  • The axis along which the arrays will be joined. If axis is None, arrays are flattened before use. Default is 0.

  • See numpy.concatenate for more information

classmethod add_concatenation_node(graph, inA, inB, outA, axis=None)[source]#

Factory method to create a concatenation kernel and add it to a graph as a generic node object.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • First input trial data

inBTensor or Scalar object

  • Second input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

axisint or tuple of ints, default = 0

  • The axis along which the arrays will be joined. If axis is None, arrays are flattened before use. Default is 0.

  • See numpy.concatenate for more information

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel function using numpy functions

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data. Called if downstream nodes are missing training data

initialize()[source]#

This kernel has no internal state that must be initialized

process_data(input_data1, input_data2, output_data)[source]#

Process input data according to outlined kernel function

verify()[source]#

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized

bcipy.kernels.covariance module#

Created on Wed Nov 20 16:20:03 2019

Covariance.py - Define the Covariance kernel for BCIP

@author: ivanovn

class bcipy.kernels.covariance.CovarianceKernel(graph, inputA, outputA, regularization)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Kernel to compute the covariance of tensors. If the input tensor is unidimensional, will compute the variance. For higher rank tensors, highest order dimension will be treated as variables and the second highest order dimension will be treated as observations.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • First input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

regularizationfloat, 0 < r < 1

  • Regularization parameter

Tensor size examples:

Input: A (kxmxn) Output: B (kxnxn)

Input: A (m) Output: B (1)

Input: A (mxn) Output: B (nxn)

Input: A (hxkxmxn) Output: B (hxkxnxn)

classmethod add_covariance_node(graph, inputA, outputA, regularization=0)[source]#

Factory method to create a covariance kernel and add it to a graph as a generic node object.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • First input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

regularizationfloat, 0 < r < 1

  • Regularization parameter

Tensor size examples:

Input: A (kxmxn) Output: B (kxnxn)

Input: A (m) Output: B (1)

Input: A (mxn) Output: B (nxn)

Input: A (hxkxmxn) Output: B (hxkxnxn)

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel function

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data. Called if downstream nodes are missing training data

initialize()[source]#

Initialize internal state and initialization output of the kernel

process_data(input_data1, output_data1)[source]#

Process input data according to outlined kernel function

verify()[source]#

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • First input trial dat

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

filtersTensor Object

  • Tensor containing precalculated spatial filters to be applied to input trial data

classmethod add_uninitialized_CSP_node(graph, inA, outA, initialization_data, labels, num_filts)[source]#

Factory method to create a CSP filter node and add it to a graph

Note that the node will have to be initialized prior to execution of the kernel.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • First input trial dat

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

initialization_dataTensor object, (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples)

  • Initialization data to train the classifier

labelsTensor object, (n_trials, )

  • Labels corresponding to initialization data class labels

num_filtsint

  • Number of spatial filters to apply to trial data.

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel by classifying the input trials

extract_filters()[source]#

Determine the filter values using the training data

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data. Called if downstream nodes are missing training data

initialize()[source]#

Set the filter values

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#

Process input data according to outlined kernel function

verify()[source]#

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized and typed

Bases: Kernel

Note: This is element-wise division

inATensor or Scalar object

  • First input trial data

inBTensor or Scalar object

  • Second input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

Note: The calculation is _inA ./ _inB

class bcipy.kernels.extract.ExtractKernel(graph, inA, indices, outA, reduce_dims)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Kernel to extract a portion of a tensor or array

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Array object

  • Input trial data

Indicieslist slices, list of ints

  • Indicies within inA from which to extract data

outATensor object

  • Extracted trial data

reduce_dimsbool, default = False

  • Remove singleton dimensions if true, don’t squeeze otherwise

@author: ivanovn

class bcipy.kernels.riemann_mdm_classifier_kernel.RiemannMDMClassifierKernel(graph, inputA, outputA, init_style, initialize_params)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Riemannian Minimum Distance to the Mean Classifier. Kernel takes Tensor input and produces scalar label representing the predicted class. Review classmethods for specific input parameters

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Array object

  • First input data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

init_styleBcipEnums Object

  • Indicates the type of classifier kernel (based by class functions)

initialize_paramsdict

  • Object passed by classmethods that contains training data and training labels

classmethod add_trained_riemann_MDM_node(graph, inputA, outputA, model)[source]#

Factory method to create a riemann minimum distance to the mean classifier kernel containing a copy of a pre-trained MDM classifier and add it to a graph as a generic node object.

The kernel will contain a reference to the model rather than making a deep-copy. Therefore any changes to the classifier object outside will effect the classifier here.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inputATensor or Array object

  • First input data

outputATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

modelMDM Classifier object

  • Existing MDM Classifier object that will be added to the node (must be pre-trained)

classmethod add_untrained_riemann_MDM_node(graph, inputA, outputA, initialization_data, labels)[source]#

Factory method to create an untrained riemann minimum distance to the mean classifier kernel and add it to a graph as a generic node object.

Note that the node will have to be initialized (i.e. trained) prior to execution of the kernel.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inputATensor or Array object

  • First input data

outputATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

initialization_dataBCIPy Tensor Object

  • Initialization data to train the classifier with (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples)

labelsBCIPy Tensor Object

  • Class labels for initialization data (n_trials,)

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel by classifying the input trials

initialize()[source]#

Set the means for the classifier

train_classifier()[source]#

Train the classifier

The method will update the kernel’s internal representation of the classifier

verify()[source]#

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized and typed

bcipy.kernels.running_average module#

Created on Thurs Aug 8 14:13:13 2022

@author: aaronlio

class bcipy.kernels.running_average.RunningAverageKernel(graph, inA, outA, running_average_cap, axis=0)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Kernel to calculate running average across multiple trials in a session. Trials are automatically included into the next running average calculation.

graphgraph object

  • The graph where the RunningAverageKernel object should be added

inATensor or Scalar object

  • Single Trial input data to the RunningAverageKernel; should be a 2D Tensor or Scalar object

outATensor/Scalar object

  • Output Tensor to store output of mean trial calculation; should be the same size of the input tensor or a scalar.

running_average_capint

  • Indicates the maximum number of trials that the running average kernel will be used to compute. Used to preallocate tensor to store previous trial data

axisNone or 0:

  • Axis by which to calculate running average. Currently only supports mean across trials when axis = 0 (ie. Average Tensor layer values), or single value mean, axis = None

classmethod add_running_average_node(graph, inA, outA, running_average_cap, axis)[source]#

Factory method to create running average node and add it to the specified graph

graphgraph object

  • The graph where the node object should be added

inATensor or scalar object

  • Single Trial input data to the RunningAverageKernel; should be a 2D Tensor or Scalar object

outATensor/Scalar object

  • Output Tensor to store output of mean trial calculation; should be the same size of the input tensor or a scalar.

running_average_capint

  • Indicates the maximum number of trials that the running average kernel will be used to compute. Used to preallocate tensor to store previous trial data

axisNone or 0:

  • Axis by which to calculate running average. Currently only supports mean across trials when axis = 0 (ie. Average Tensor layer values), or single value mean, axis = None

execute()[source]#

Add input data to data object storing previous trials and process the stacked data

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data

initialize()[source]#

This kernel has no internal state to be initialized. Call initialization_execution if downstream nodes are missing training data.

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#

Process data according to the outlined kernel function

verify()[source]#

Generic verification abstract method to be defined by individual kernels.

bcipy.kernels.std module#

Created on Fri Mar 6 11:14:30 2020

@author: ivanovn

class bcipy.kernels.std.StdKernel(graph, inA, outA, axis, ddof)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Calculates the standard deviation of values in a tensor

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor object

  • First input trial data

outATensor object

  • Output trial data

axisNone or int or tuple of ints, optional

  • Axis or axes along which the standard deviation is computed. The default is to compute the standard deviation of the flattened array.

ddofint, optional

  • Means Delta Degrees of Freedom. The divisor used in calculations is N - ddof, where N represents the number of elements. By default ddof is zero.

class bcipy.kernels.tangent_space.TangentSpaceKernel(graph, inA, outA, initialization_data, metric='riemann', tsupdate=False, sample_weight=None)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Kernel to estimate Tangent Space. Applies Pyriemann.tangentspace method

inATensor object

  • Input data

outATensor object

  • Output data

initialization_dataTensor object

  • Data to initialize the estimator with (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples)

metricstr, default = ‘riemann’

  • See pyriemann.tangentspace for more info

metricbool, default = False

  • See pyriemann.tangentspace for more info

sample_weightndarray, or None, default = None

  • sample of each weight. If none, all samples have equal weight

  • See pyriemann.tangentspace for more info

  • sample of each weight. If none, all samples have equal weight

bcipy.kernels.transpose module#

Created on Thu Nov 20 18:20:03 2019

Transpose.py - Define the transpose kernel for BCIP

@author: ivanovn

class bcipy.kernels.transpose.TransposeKernel(graph, inputA, outputA, axes)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Kernel to compute the tensor transpose

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inputATensor or Scalar object

  • Input trial data

outputATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

axestuple or list of ints, optional

  • If specified, it must be a tuple or list which contains a permutation of [0,1,..,N-1] where N is the number of axes of a. The i’th axis of the returned array will correspond to the axis numbered axes[i] of the input. If not specified, defaults to range(a.ndim)[::-1], which reverses the order of the axes.

classmethod add_transpose_node(graph, inputA, outputA, axes=None)[source]#

Factory method to create a transpose kernel and add it to a graph as a generic node object.

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inputATensor or Scalar object

  • Input trial data

outputATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

axestuple or list of ints, default = None

  • If specified, it must be a tuple or list which contains a permutation of [0,1,..,N-1] where N is the number of axes of a. The i’th axis of the returned array will correspond to the axis numbered axes[i] of the input. If not specified, defaults to range(a.ndim)[::-1], which reverses the order of the axes.

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel function using the numpy transpose function

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data. Called when downstream nodes are missing training data

initialize()[source]#

This kernel has no internal state that must be initialized

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#

Process data according to outlined kernel function

verify()[source]#

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized

bcipy.kernels.var module#

Created on Sun Apr 5 17:13:07 2020

@author: Nick

class bcipy.kernels.var.VarKernel(graph, inA, outA, axis, ddof, keep_dims)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Calculates the variance of values in a tensor

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • Input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

axisNone or int or tuple of ints, optional

  • Axis or axes along which the variance is computed. The default is to compute the variance of the flattened array.

ddofint, optional

  • “Delta Degrees of Freedom”: the divisor used in the calculation is N - ddof, where N represents the number of elements. By default ddof is zero.

keepdimsbool, optional

  • If this is set to True, the axes which are reduced are left in the result as dimensions with size one. With this option, the result will broadcast correctly against the input array.

classmethod add_var_node(graph, inA, outA, axis=None, ddof=0, keep_dims=False)[source]#

Factory method to create a variance kernel

graphGraph Object

  • Graph that the kernel should be added to

inATensor or Scalar object

  • Input trial data

outATensor or Scalar object

  • Output trial data

axisNone or int or tuple of ints, optional

  • Axis or axes along which the variance is computed. The default is to compute the variance of the flattened array.

ddofint, optional

  • “Delta Degrees of Freedom”: the divisor used in the calculation is N - ddof, where N represents the number of elements. By default ddof is zero.

keepdimsbool, optional

  • If this is set to True, the axes which are reduced are left in the result as dimensions with size one. With this option, the result will broadcast correctly against the input array.

execute()[source]#

Execute the kernel and calculate the mean

initialization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data. Called if downstream nodes are missing training data

initialize()[source]#

This kernel has no internal state that must be initialized

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#

Process data according to outlined kernel function.

Verify the inputs and outputs are appropriately sized and typed

bcipy.kernels.xdawn_covariances module#

Created on Fri Aug 12 14:53:29 2022

xdawn_covariances.py - Calculates the Xdawn covariances

@author: aaronlio

class bcipy.kernels.xdawn_covariances.XDawnCovarianceKernel(graph, inA, outA, initialization_data, labels, num_filters=4, applyfilters=True, classes=None, estimator='scm', xdawn_estimator='scm', baseline_cov=None)[source]#

Bases: Kernel

Kernel to estimate special form covariance matrices for ERP combined with Xdawn

inATensor object

  • Input data

outATensor object

  • Output data

initialization_dataTensor object

  • Data to initialize the estimator with (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples)

labelsTensor object

  • Class labels for initialization data

nfilterint, default=4

  • Number of Xdawn filters per class.

applyfiltersbool, default=True

  • If true, spatial filter are applied to the prototypes and the signals. If False, filters are applied only to the ERP prototypes allowing for a better generalization across subject and session at the expense of dimensionality increase. In that case, the estimation is similar to pyriemann.estimation.ERPCovariances with svd=nfilter but with more compact prototype reduction.

classeslist of int | None, default=None

  • list of classes to take into account for prototype estimation. If None, all classes will be accounted.

estimatorstring, default=’scm’

  • Covariance matrix estimator, see pyriemann.utils.covariance.covariances().

xdawn_estimatorstring, default=’scm’

  • Covariance matrix estimator for Xdawn spatial filtering. Should be regularized using ‘lwf’ or ‘oas’, see pyriemann.utils.covariance.covariances().

baseline_covarray, shape (n_chan, n_chan) | None, default=None

  • Baseline covariance for Xdawn spatial filtering, see pyriemann.spatialfilters.Xdawn

classmethod add_xdawn_covariance_kernel(graph, inA, outA, initialization_data, labels, num_filters=4, applyfilters=True, classes=None, estimator='scm', xdawn_estimator='scm', baseline_cov=None)[source]#

Factory method to create xdawn_covariance kernel, add it to a node, and add the node to the specified graph.

inATensor object

  • Input data

outATensor object

  • Output data

initialization_dataTensor object

  • Data to initialize the estimator with (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples)

labelsTensor object

  • Class labels for initialization data

nfilterint, default=4

  • Number of Xdawn filters per class.

applyfiltersbool, default=True

  • If true, spatial filter are applied to the prototypes and the signals. If False, filters are applied only to the ERP prototypes allowing for a better generalization across subject and session at the expense of dimensionality increase. In that case, the estimation is similar to pyriemann.estimation.ERPCovariances with svd=nfilter but with more compact prototype reduction.

classeslist of int | None, default=None

  • list of classes to take into account for prototype estimation. If None, all classes will be accounted.

estimatorstring, default=’scm’

  • Covariance matrix estimator, see pyriemann.utils.covariance.covariances().

xdawn_estimatorstring, default=’scm’

  • Covariance matrix estimator for Xdawn spatial filtering. Should be regularized using ‘lwf’ or ‘oas’, see pyriemann.utils.covariance.covariances().

baseline_covarray, shape (n_chan, n_chan) | None, default=None

  • Baseline covariance for Xdawn spatial filtering, see pyriemann.spatialfilters.Xdawn

execute()[source]#

Execute processing of trial data

initialize()[source]#

Initialize the internal state of the kernel. Fit the xdawn_estimator classifier, etc.

initilization_execution()[source]#

Process initialization data if downstream nodes are missing training data

process_data(input_data, output_data)[source]#

Process input data according to outlined kernel function

verify()[source]#

Generic verification abstract method to be defined by individual kernels.
